questions.question: What is the most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children?
Which of the following conditions does not presents as pulsatile proptosis?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, hemangioma will not present with pulsatile proptosis.Causes of pulsatile proptosis:• Pulsating vascular lesions:• Caroticocavernous fistula- most common• Saccular aneurysm of ophthalmic artery•Transmitted cerebral pulsations in conditions with a deficient orbital roof:430•• Congenital meningocele/meningoencephalocele• Neurofibromatosis•• Traumatic or operative hiatusCauses of intermittent proptosis:•• Orbital varix- most common• Periodic orbital edemaCauses of reducible proptosis:• Orbital varix•Hemangioma• Caroticocavernous fistula

questions.question: A patient presents with unilateral non-pulsatile proptosis, which is compressible andincreases on bending forward. No thrill or bruit is present. MRI shows a retrobulbar masswith enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The likely diagnosis from the above clinical scenario is orbital varix.The type of proptosis seen in orbital varix is non-pulsatile, intermittent, and reducible proptosis.On activities such as forward bending or lowering of the head, turning the head forcefully,hyperextension of the neck, and coughing, the varices fill up, causing proptosis, and then, theyregress on shifting to a non-dependent position.All the other conditions listed, namely, carotid cavernous fistula, orbital encephalocele, andneurofibromatosis, present with pulsatile proptosis.

questions.question: A 26-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the head 2 months earlier presented withrapidly progressive swelling, pain, and diminishing vision in the left eye. The physicalexamination of the left eye revealed chemosis and pulsating proptosis. A bruit could be heard422with a stethoscope placed on the left temple. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of carotid-cavernous fistula.All the given options are causes of proptosis following trauma, but among these, only acarotid-cavernous fistula presents with the classic triad:• Pulsatile proptosis• Chemosis• BruitSelective carotid angiography is the investigation of choice.A carotid-cavernous fistula requires a definitive treatment, which currently involvesthe endovascular technique. The fistula can usually be occluded with a balloon or coil, without thesacrifice of the carotid artery.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions will present with pseudoproptosis?
questions.explanation: 431Buphthalmos causes pseudoproptosis.The other listed conditions, namely, pseudotumors, orbital hemorrhage, and cavernous sinusthrombosis, produce actual proptosis.Pseudoproptosis is a condition in which the eyeball appears to be proptosed, but there is no actualforward displacement.Causes of pseudoproptosis:Buphthalmos is the term used when the eyeball enlarges in children who develop congenitalglaucoma before the age of 3 years.•Axial high myopia- increase in the size of the eyeball in myopia causes pseudoproptosis• Retraction of the upper lid•Enophthalmos of the opposite eye

questions.question: A 48-year-old lady presents with unilateral mild axial proptosis. On examination, thefollowing nail and skin changes were seen as shown. Which of the following is the mostappropriate next step of investigation?

options.A: CT scan to rule out meningioma
options.B: USG to rule out orbital pseudotumor
options.C: T3 and T4 measurement to check for thyrotoxicosisDAILYROUNDS423

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the image showing thyroid acropachy and dermopathy issuggestive of Graves' disease. The most appropriate next step of the investigation is T3 and T4measurement to check for thyrotoxicosis.Thyroid ophthalmopathy is the most common cause of proptosis in adults, which may presentas unilateral or bilateral, axial or non-axial, painful or painless proptosis.The image given below shows unilateral proptosis in the right eye.DAILYROUNDS

questions.question: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, andchemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.432Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis inan adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis,periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.Other options-Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements periorbital edema,erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as apainless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually a unilateral condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis.NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

questions.question: What is the most common clinical feature of Graves' ophthalmopathy?
questions.explanation: Dalrymple's sign (retraction of the upper lids) is the most common clinical feature of Graves'ophthalmopathy. It is caused by the overaction of Muller's muscle. Levator palpebrae superioris(LPS) recession surgery may be done to correct upper lid retraction.The image given below shows Dalrymple's sign (retraction of the upper lids) in the right eye:DAILYROUNDSNOSPECS classification by Werner reflecting the severity of thyroid ophthalmopathy.Class01DefinitionNo physical signs or symptomsOnly signs, no symptoms (signs limited to upper lid retraction, stare, lid lag, and proptosis of up to 22 mm)433Class23456NOSPECS:No signs or symptoms; Only signs; Soft tissue; Proptosis; Extraocular muscle; Cornea;Sight lossDefinitionSoft tissue involvement (symptom and signs)ProptosisExtraocular muscle involvementCorneal involvementSight loss (optic nerve involvement)

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presents with heat intolerance and weight loss for the past few weeks. Hehas lost 10 kgs despite having an increased appetite. On examination, he has a fine tremor ofthe hands, and his thyroid is enlarged. Lab investigations reveal low TSH and elevated T3 andT4. What is the most common ocular motility defect seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Grave's disease. The most common ocular motilitydefect seen in Grave's disease is elevator restriction.It occurs due to the fibrotic contracture of the inferior rectus muscle. The inferior rectus musclehas to relax during the elevation of the eye. The fibrosis of the muscle restricts its relaxation andthus elevation of the eye is restricted.There is an inability to look up (in both adducted and abducted positions) along with esotropia(fibrosis of the medial rectus).Only the belly of the muscle is involved in thyroid myopathy; the tendon is characteristicallyspared.Ocular motility restriction in order of frequency is as follows:•• Elevation defect• Abduction defect, due to fibrosis of the medial rectus•Depression defect, due to fibrosis of the superior rectus•• Adduction defect, due to fibrosis of the lateral rectus

questions.question: What is known as the infrequent blinking seen in Graves' ophthalmopathy?
questions.explanation: Infrequent blinking is known as Stellwag's sign.

questions.question: A lady is referred from the medicine department for an eye exam due to gritty sensation inher eyes. She is a known case of hyperthyroidism. Her ophthalmic examination shows thefollowing finding along with the inability to look up. Which of the following is not a treatmentmodality for this condition?
questions.explanation: 434The clinical scenario of grittiness in the eyes (due to ocular dryness), hyperthyroidism and theimage showing exophthalmos are suggestive of Graves ophthalmopathy.Beta-blockers are not indicated in the treatment of graves ophthalmopathy, however, they areused in the symptomatic management of hyperthyroidism.Treatment of thyroid ophthalmopathy:(A) Non-surgical management• Systemic steroids- These form the mainstay of the treatment. Oral, intravenous or orbital steroidinjections can be used depending upon patient indications. (Option B)•Radiotherapy- Orbital radiation given in a dose of 2000 rads over 10-14 days can be consideredin cases where steroids are ineffective/ contraindicated. It is contraindicated in cases of extensivethyroid eye disease as it can worsen it. (Option A)• Teprotumumab (IGF-1R inhibitor)- is used for persistent, corticosteroid-resistant disease ornon-response to first-line treatment. It is effective in reducing proptosis and clinical activity inpatients.(B) Surgical management:• Orbital decompression- It may be required for an acutely progressive optic neuropathy and/orexposure keratitis, in patients not responding to aggressive steroid therapy. (Option D)• Extraocular muscle surgery- Inferior rectus recession is the most commonly performed surgery.These should be performed after the orbital decompression since decompression may alterextraocular motility. Extraocular muscle surgery helps in achieving a binocular single vision in theprimary gaze and reading position.•• Eyelid surgery- This is done to correct eyelid retraction. Various surgeries that can be performedare mullerectomy, levator recession/ disinsertion, scleral grafts with LPS recession, recession oflower eyelid retractors, and blepharoplasty.

questions.question: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the mostprobable cause?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis include early involvement lateral rectus palsy (abducentnerve involvement) since it runs through the cavernous sinus. Oculomotor and trochlear nervepalsy occur later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Other signs areproptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in the mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation,and dilated pupil.Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis withleukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.Option B- Orbital pseudotumor presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctivalchemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocularmotility.435Pituitary glandCavernous sinusOMARROWInternal carotid arteryOculomotor nerve (III)Trochlear nerve (IV)Abducent nerve (VI)Ophthalmic division oftrigeminal nerve (V₁)Maxillary division oftrigeminal nerve (V2)

questions.question: A 20-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use ofnasal decongestants presents to the OPD with high-grade fever and chills, headache, andbilateral proptosis. On further history, it is noted that the proptosis began in the right eye,and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.Pain over the medial canthus and use of nasal decongestants indicate that the patient wassuffering from sinusitis, which can spread to cause orbital cellulitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis,or panopthalmitis.The differentiating feature here is the presentation pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis.In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due tothe spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through intercavernous communication. Also,cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache.On the other hand, orbital cellulitis and panophthalmitis are unilateral conditions.Differential diagnosis of acute inflammatory proptosis:Clinical featuresLateralityVisionCornea and anterior chamberEdema in the mastoid regionGeneral symptoms with feverand prostrationCavernous sinus thrombosisInitially unilateral but soon becomes bilateralOrbital cellulitisUnilateralPanophthalmitisUnilateralNot affected in early stageClearaffectedComplete loss of visionClearHazyPresent(Pathognomonic of cavernous sinus thrombosis)MarkedAbsentAbsentMildMild436

questions.question: Among the following, which muscle is affected first in cavernous sinus thrombosis?
questions.explanation: The first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is the lateral rectus.Ophthalmoplegia in cavernous sinus thrombosis occurs in the following sequence:•6th nerve palsy (lateral rectus palsy) occurring first of all as it passes through the cavernoussinus.•3rd and 4th nerves are involved later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernoussinus.Cavernous sinusPituitary glandOMARROWInternal carotid arteryOculomotor nerve (III)Trochlear nerve (IV)Abducent nerve (VI)Ophthalmic division oftrigeminal nerve (V₁)Maxillary division oftrigeminal nerve (V2)

questions.question: MRI of a patient revealed features of right cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of thefollowing would not be seen in this patient?

options.A: Constricted right pupil in response to light

questions.explanation: Dilation of the pupil will be seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis due to the involvement of the 3rdcranial nerve.Cavernous sinusPituitary glandOMARROW437Internal carotid arteryOculomotor nerve (III)Trochlear nerve (IV)Abducent nerve (VI)Ophthalmic division oftrigeminal nerve (V₁)Maxillary division oftrigeminal nerve (V2)

questions.question: A 40-year-old male presented with a 1-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral periorbitaland mid-facial swelling. He had attempted to burst a furuncle in the inner margin of his rightnostril 2 days back. On examination, marked facial and periorbital swelling with chemosisand proptosis are noted. MRI is suggestive of bilateral cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of426the following veins is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation: Infection from the dangerous area of the face (the area from the corners of the mouth to thebridge of the nose, including the nose and maxilla) spreads to the cavernous sinus viathe ophthalmic veins.Communication between facial vein andcavernous sinusSuperior ophthalmic veinCavernoussinusPterygoid plexusDeep facial veinOMARROW-InferiorophthalmicveinFacial vein

questions.question: A child is brought to the OPD with fever, severe pain, and swelling of the left eye. He wasbitten by a dog over the eye a few days back. On examination, there is mild proptosis withrestriction of ocular movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of orbital cellulitis.It is the acute inflammation of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. It can occurdue to exogenous infection (penetrating injuries) or extension of an endogenous infection (dentalinfection).It presents with fever, severe pain, and eye swelling which increases with movement, chemosis,axial proptosis, and restriction of ocular movements. Complications include subperiosteal abscess,orbital abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, and general septicemia.The image shows orbital cellulitis in the left eye.438DAILYROUNDSOption B: Endophthalmitis is defined as the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball,i.e., uveal tissue and retina, associated with the pouring of exudates into the vitreous cavity,anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.Option C: Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball, includingTenon's capsule.Option D: Preseptal cellulitis refers to infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbitalseptum. In this condition, proptosis is absent and ocular movements are normal.

questions.question: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and painful swelling of the left eye. He is being treatedfor acute ethmoiditis for 5 days. On examination, the visual acuity in the left eye is 6/12, thereis chemosis, axial proptosis, limitation of ocular motility in all directions, and RAPD. What isthe most likely diagnosis?427
questions.explanation: The most likely diagnosis of this patient is orbital cellulitis.Orbital cellulitis is the most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children. Ethmoidal sinusitisis the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in children.Orbital cellulitis presents with pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis.Decreased ocular motility and elevated intraocular pressure can be seen. Systemic symptomsinclude malaise and fever. A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve. Withposterior exenteration cavernous sinus thrombosis, subdural empyema, and intracranial abscessdevelop.WARNING SIGNS: Dilated pupil, marked ophthalmoplegia, loss of vision, afferent pupillarydefect, papilledema, and violaceous lids.

questions.question: What is the surgery of choice for panophthalmitis?
questions.explanation: The surgery of choice for panophthalmitis is an evisceration. Evisceration gives a better cosmeticoutlook after the surgery and is hence preferred. Enucleation is contraindicated inpanophthalmitis due to the risk of meningitis through the exposed meningeal sheath of the optic439nerve stump.Some definitions:•• Evisceration- removal of the contents of the eyeball, leaving behind the sclera. It is donein panophthalmitis.•Enucleation-removal of the eyeball, with the maximum part of the optic nerve. Extraocularmuscles are left behind. The length of the optic nerve removed is 10 to 15 mm. Absoluteindications for enucleation are retinoblastoma and malignant melanoma.•• Exenteration- mutilating surgery in which all the contents of the orbits along with the periorbitaare removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreadingfrom the eyeball.•Debulking- reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays,debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

questions.question: A 72-year-old female presents with normal visual acuity, diminished corneal sensation, andglobal impairment of ocular motility of the right eye. The patient also has a severe boringheadache. The MRI shows an enhancing mass within the right cavernous sinus. The pain andophthalmoplegia respond dramatically to corticosteroid therapy. What is the most likelydiagnosis?

options.B: Meningioma of the cavernous sinusInternal carotid aneurysmd) Tolosa- Hunt syndromeQuestion 21:The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome isbest made by the dysfunction of which cranial nerve?a) CN IIb) CN III

questions.explanation: The patient presents with acute ophthalmoplegia with the involvement of ophthalmic division oftrigeminal nerve that responds promptly to steroid therapy. The most likely diagnosis isTolosa-Hunt syndrome.It is an idiopathic, sterile inflammation that primarily affects the cavernous sinus. It ischaracterized by painful acute ophthalmoplegia with or without the involvement of the optic nerveand the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.The pain is described as gnawing or boring and may precede ophthalmoplegia.The inflammation and pain in patients typically responds rapidly and dramatically tocorticosteroid therapy. However, it is a diagnosis of exclusion.

questions.question: A patient was being evaluated for retro-orbital pain in the ward. After multiple investigations,he was diagnosed with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome. Which of the following findings will not beseen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Ipsilateral lateral rectus palsy due to 6th cranial nerve involvement is seen in Tolosa-Huntsyndrome, not contralateral.440Tolosa-Hunt syndrome refers to idiopathic, nonspecific, granulomatous inflammation, involvingthe superior orbital fissure and/or orbital apex and/or cavernous sinus. It is a unilateral eyecondition.Clinically, it manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and depending on the extent of involvement, itmay present as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome.Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the following:•• Pain, typically labeled as retro-orbital acheSensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve• Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to the involvement of the 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerveinvolvement• Ptosis, due to 3rd nerve paralysisOrbital apex syndrome includes the following:• Features of superior orbital fissure syndrome described above•• Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e., early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.441
